Thanks Elena and Stefan - that make sense.
hmm...that seems to be a good point of view. Tested only on a simplex setup, didn't think about the swact case you mentioned.

the flags on controller-0 are created at ansible bootstrap time and the same flags should be created on controller-1 at first unlock. Since a swact requires both nodes to be unlocked and available, I don't think there is any chance of a swact where only one node has these flags.

Since LVs are created independently between controllers, the wipes should be done independently between controllers. Even for drbd-synced LVs, first we create the LV and then DRBD comes over it, so wiping the end of the LV at creation (and resize) should be safe.

What happens with this code during upgrades? If we upgrade from version N to N+1, the code at version N will not have created the flag file, but when this code at version N+1 will reach this, it will start wiping the beginning and end of each partition.

Since these partition will have data on them, deleting 10MB at the beginning and end of each partition at this time will most likely delete actual data.
True. Completely forgot about the wiping of the whole rootfs during upgrades.
we wipe rootfs on upgrades, so not a problem, it won't have data on them.

10MB is a lot of data to delete in the event of a resize. what happens if the partition is full (or almost full) and we do a resize? Isn't there the risk of deleting actual data and not just DRBD/filesystem metadata?

Minimum resize is +1GB, so not an issue if we wipe 10MB at the end.

Also, lv resize with the same size should not pass sysinv semantics (the code here exists for a long time, and didn't cause any issues).
Agreed. Since the wipe happens after we resize the LV and we can only resize in increment of 1GB, wiping the 10MB at the end should be safe.

elasticsearch/templates/bin/_elasticsear.message: The drain_data_node function is just a trap on the listed signals - it doesn't get executed before allocate in this case

I'd also suggest reconsidering the existence of a file being the determining factor of whether you allocate the node or do nothing. If it takes longer to drain the node than the graceful termination period allows, it's likely that the kubelet is issuing SIGKILL because your nodes are taking too long to drain, which means that the file you're expecting will not exist when the pods are recreated, explaining the scenario where nothing happens

You absolutely do want to trap the signal and drain the data node, specifically in upgrade scenarios - failure to do so will result in unallocated shards, which will lead to significantly longer recovery times when the pods are recreated and come back online.

Currently there is an issue that some labs after upgrade the allocation setting remains persistent. The only function call this setting is in "drain_data_node function. the only function to reset the setting is in allocate_data_node. allocate_data_node() checks file /data/restarting and if no such file, it will do nothing. I think there is logical bug that if allocate_data_node() starts too soon, it will finish before drain_data_node create "/data/restarting". So we need set the order. I don't think we need consider the exit signal for drain_data_node, just need to be sure allocation_data_node() is after drain_data_node
Since we're not checking for a restart condition anymore, we should probably change to this to 'started' for clarity

zuul.d/projects.yaml.message: why run periodic and not as deploy job when gerrit/projects.yaml changes?
You're right - I missed the closing of open PRs. In that case, I'm fine leaving it here in periodic.

The script does more than create new repositories. It does all GitHub mirror maintenance operations, including for example closing open PRs on gitHub. So it's important that it runs at least daily.

We could run it on projects.yaml changes in addition to that, for immediate effect, but I think it needs to stay in the periodic pipeline too.

specs/stein/approved/glance/image-encryp.message:
I'd like you to be more clear about the problem you want to solve.  What I mean is, Glance currently controls access to an image by what 'visibility' is set on the image.  Private images are accessible only within a project, not outside a project.

But, you say, what if someone gains access to the Glance backend?  Suppose someone does, even with the image encrypted.  If that person has access to the key stored in Barbican, then the encryption does not guarantee the confidentiality of the image data.

Similarly, when nova decrypts the data in-flight from Glance, the image is going to wind up unencrypted on the hypervisor.  So now we're in the same situation as if the image were never encrypted and someone compromised the Glance backend.  If someone got hypervisor access at this point, they'd have access to the image.

So it's not clear to me why a plaintext image is OK on the hypervisor but not in the Glance backend.
Done

If someone gains access to both the Glance host file system as well as the Barbican key entry it's game over for the image, I agree. However, gaining access to one does not automatically grant access to the other. As a Defence-in-depth approach this still holds value for sufficiently secured infrastructures.

Regarding the hypervisor: as described in "Proposed change" we require the mechanism to be able to directly stream the image format into the target resource (volumes, ephemeral disks). If the target is encrypted as well and native LUKS (QEMU) is used, the image data is never exposed unencrypted anywhere else than in the hypervisor for the VM itself. Even root can't access it.

There are still limitations (native LUKS only supported by volumes not ephemeral storage etc.) but in specific scenarios you can already reach this level of security - it's up to the provider to limit the possibility scenarios through configuration if they care about that. We would limit them in the code itself but Nova and Cinder teams have been against this approach, so we simply lay the foundation for security focused clouds. It's not like it is OK to have plaintext images on the hypervisor and our proposal doesn't state that.

We simply can't address every possible cloud configuration in the same way. But with a set of configuration recommendations for security focused environments, we are able to reach a good foundation in our opinion. Future enhancements can build upon that and extend the provided security enhancements to a broader set of variants.

Could you clarify the sense in which this is a "secret ID"?  What I mean is, do you simply mean that this is the identifier for the key stored in barbican, or do you mean that you want to keep this ID itself secret (perhaps by using property protections to make it invisible to most users)?
Done
We do not plan to keep the ID itself secret, it’s simply an identifier for the key stored in Barbican. It’s similar to the ‘encryption_key_id’ for resources in other services (volumes etc.).
How is access to this key controlled?
As with any other secret stored in Barbican the access is controlled by the project/role assignment of the user. Similar to encryption keys attached to volumes or ephemeral disks.
Done

I think you'll need something like this:
- a new container_format, 'encrypted'
- custom image properties:
  * os_encrypt_method - stores the encryption algo identifier
  * os_encrypt_key_id - reference to the key in barbican
  * os_decrypt_container_format - value is the container format after the payload is decrypted
Done

This what we intended basically. In addition to the container_format, we’d like to propose the following slightly different set of metadata:

* os_encrypt_format - the main mechanism used, e.g. 'GPG'
* os_encrypt_type   - encryption type, e.g. 'symmetric'
* os_encrypt_cipher - the cipher algorithm, e.g. 'AES256'
* os_encrypt_key_id - reference to key in barbican
* os_decrypt_container_format - format after payload decryption

This way we don't limit the possibilities for future extensions too much. The addition of "os_decrypt_container_format" seems reasonable to me and pursues the same goal I guess. Currently, our  implementation only supports raw format but no reason to stay limited to this in the future.

I think it's worth stating explicitly here what you said on the other patch, namely that making this completely secure will depend upon proper configuration by the cloud provider, for example, making sure no in-flight-decrypted images are cached on the nova compute.  Your aim is to make sure that the tools are available so that a cloud can be securely configured.

Another way to do this would be to leave the image un-encrypted but have the data payload inside the image be encrypted.  Once the image is booted, a script goes out to some trusted keyserver outside the cloud, gets the key and decrypts the payload.  This would have the advantage that the cloud provider would have no way to decrypt the data, so the user's audit chain doesn't depend on the trustworthiness of the cloud provider.  Could you explain why your proposal is as good/better than this idea?  (I'm not saying your idea is bad, I'm trying to get a better understanding of how your proposal solves the audit chain problem.)

(I don't know if I understood what you are describing correctly, so for my answer I'll assume you meant that the user has to include an encrypted data package and corresponding script as part of their image, which is executed after the server boot.)

This is something the user could already do with OpenStack in its current state. The user is free to include any additional script and data in their image as long as the cloud-init works. In this case however, the user has to have the expertise and ability to set up such an infrastructure, including the external trusted keyserver and secure encryption mechanism. This also kind of denies the cloud idea in my opinion since all of this relies on an external infrastructure which is not part of the cloud.

With our proposal we want to include a new core functionality to OpenStack that enables cloud users without sufficient expertise and infrastructure (keyserver) to protect the data in their images using encryption according to a supported standard. The functionality is supposed to be provided by the OpenStack services and OSC, so the user doesn't have to adjust their images in any way and can rely on the services that OpenStack offers.

Furthermore, in the case you described, if the included script goes out to the "trusted keyserver" and decrypts the data all by itself, how is the data protected if an unauthorized entity is able to retrieve the image file and simply boots it (which will start the data decryption automatically)?

Well, the request to the keyserver would contain some kind of info that the keyserver could use to validate the request.  For example, the request could contain the UUID of the VM and the keyserver would contact the Compute API and verify the owner, IP, etc., before responding with the key.

But I take your point that this would not be something easy for the average user to set up.  On the other hand, is your proposal in fact going to satisfy privacy audit requirements if the user is running in a public cloud?  And is your proposal useful in a private cloud (doesn't seem like it would be necessary)?

This is another scenario that could be accomplished by using an external keyserver outside the cloud, creating an encrypted data package, and then using shred or something on the ephemeral disk; the image uploaded to glance wouldn't be encrypted, but the part you care about would be.
If the image isn't encrypted (just the data is), then you don't need to worry about this scenario.
Same here, if the image isn't encrypted, then this isn't a problem.
Could there be a situation where this key isn't stored in barbican?
would it be worth enforcing (or having an administrator configurable limit) on minimum key size?
think the "d" here can be removed
list all others which where tested?
I imagine some administrators will want to force encryption to always be used?
Something is wrong gramatically here. Perhaps "An end user should have documentation on how to use encrypted images."
This document only talks about symmetric keys. What other types of keys do you anticipate supporting? Do we need to record the type if the value is always the same?
I'm wondering what value this brings even if asymmetric keys are to be used? Shouldn't this be part of the cipher identifier specified below?

We only propose a symmetric encryption and corresponding workflow for images. This doesn't mean that there won't be an asymmetric mechanism added in the future eventually. We just want to avoid limiting the extension possibilities too much.
Does this need to match one of the driver names in the proposed oslo.encrypt library?

We intend oslo.encrypt to provide a method that takes the relevant 'os_encrypt_*' values (format, type, cipher) as input and returns a matching driver implementing that specific crypto. This is a more dynamic approach, which allows for easy exchange of cryptographic implementations instead of locking the image resource to a specific driver.
Is there ever meaningful difference?

Yes, there is a difference, either through compressing the whole image or "snapshoting" an ephemeral storage. In the latter case the encryption layer adds a few bytes and it would not be possible to use the same flavor used for the original server also for another server you want to create from the snapshot.
I don't think we can prevent any such decisions. Maybe "eliminate the need of"?
Done

This section doesn't spell out whether Glance will delete keys from Barbican when images are deleted.  I believe this functionality should maintain a 1:1 relationship between keys and images, which means it would need to do this.
Done

I tend to disagree here. As Glance does not create, "own" nor manage the keys it should not be just randomly deleting them either. I really really hate the idea and the possible horror stories coming out of it, if we started deleting the keys, which lifecycle we haven't been controlling from the beginning, on behalf of the user. I don't think we have any mechanism to enforce uniqueness of the key IDs used within the cloud across the services either.

It would be a good idea to add a section here on "Key Handling" to explain the envisioned workflow for how end users (and administrators, if there's a different flow for them) will manage their keys, and what role (if any) Glance/Cinder/Nova will have in key management.  IIRC, Eric's question has come up in previous discussion, and it would be good to have an explicit answer in the text.  (It will also be a useful reference when the time comes for documentation and release notes.)

I just want to register that I am 100% against changing the data model for this.  What we can do is describe them using image metadefs, as we currently do for the image signature verification metadata:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/glance/tree/etc/metadefs/image-signature-verification.json
How should the REST API respond if the cloud does not have a key manager configured?

5XX is almost never good intentional response. I think 403 Forbidden would be the only properly acceptable response in the case the deployment does not support the key manager and thus cannot complete the request.

I think we should include identifier for this into the discoverability API so the user can check it before.

I don't think the Images API needs to do anything in this case.  Glance isn't doing encryption or decryption, it's just storing the image, so not having access to the key won't affect Glance.  If a user uploads an encrypted image first, and then discovers that there's no Barbican present to store the key, then the user can simply delete the image.  If the user tries to upload the key first, at that point they'll discover that there's no Barbican, and presumably they won't upload an encrypted image to Glance.

Any specific suggestions for the REST API behavior in this case?

I guess the requests should simply return an error, like 501 or something else appropriate.

specs/stein/approved/index.rst.message: I don't think this file needs to be included on this patch.

specs/train/approved/glance/image-encryp.message: It seems kind of strange to call this a format -- how about 'os_encrypt_mechanism'?  (If 'format' is the term used for this in cryptographic circles, feel free to ignore this comment.)
Just want to follow up on Erno's question from the previous draft about whether we really need this one -- we already have min_disk and virtual_size, would one of those work?
This 'Consumer API' in Barbican looks really useful.
I think it would make sense for these to be "common image properties".  See the "Proposed Change" section of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/656895/ for a discussion of what this would mean.

One last appeal here for 'mechanism', or for a better explanation of 'format' (I'm not a cryptographer.)  A super-paranoid user may want to upload pre-encrypted raw bits to Glance and then set the proper metadata.  Suppose this user uses PGP Desktop (with AES256) algo because that's what they have available.  Would that user enter 'PGP' for this field?  What I'm getting at is that the *format* of the blob should be the same whether the user uses GPG or PGP to encrypt the data.

I can see a reason to have this info: suppose there's some kind of weird bug that under certain circumstances creates output that isn't interoperable between GPG and PGP; knowing the mechanism used could be helpful for debugging a failure.  But is that the point of this field?  Please explain.  We need to have a clear explanation of this for the documentation.

I agree that the term ‚format‘ might be inappropriate for the current proposal. We refrained from using ‚driver‘ so far because it sounded a bit too server-centric from our point of view. The idea was that the field would not describe the exact driver to be selected but rather give a strong hint to which one is most likely able to handle it. The other fields would then be used to further narrow down the specific driver selection.
The benefit would be that the tools used on either side (client or server) to process the format could vary as long as the format agreed on can be processed by both. The documentation should then state which formats and combinations are currently supported and provide examples which tools on the user side may be used. I understand that this might be error-prone due to ever so slight differences between implementations.

Would you suggest that we reduce this to a fixed selection of drivers and specific driver names for the user to choose from along with a documentation on how each exact format supported by a driver may be generated on user side?

Sorry I wasn't clear about what I'm asking about.  I understand the reason for the field, I'm just confused by its name.  A "format" is usually understood as an end result, i.e., a file that is structured in a specific way.  Since we're talking about the mechanism that is doing the structuring, I don't think 'format' is the correct term.

Given what you say above, though (that the field will be used by the code to select the driver to use), maybe this field should be named 'os_encrypt_driver'?  What would be the allowable values?  How would you explain what's supposed to go here to someone uploading an already encrypted image (or are you not supporting that use case)?

The way we intend the library (os-brick) to be structured regarding the crypto function is in a driver-based fashion. For the initial implementation, we propose to use an implementation of symmetric AES256 encryption as provided by GnuPG (GPG). For example, the corresponding values defining this implementation are: 'GPG' (format/mechanism), 'AES256' (cipher), 'symmetric' (type).

When the library is called to handle an encryption, a corresponding driver is selected which offers handling for the exact combination given (or throws an error if that combination can't be handled by any of the available drivers). This is similar to how secret orders work in Barbican.

Thus, the format/mechanism field is intended to be the main identifier for the driver, whereas cipher and type are rather weak identifiers in comparison. The main focus here is to get reproducible results, i.e. if I do a symmetric AES256 encryption using GPG, I should get the same results regardless on which system.
You never answered Erno's question from the PS4 about whether we really need this one -- we already have min_disk and virtual_size, would one of those work?

As already agreed upon in the IRC, we will stick with introducing a new field for the decrypted size. It is strictly related to the encryption of an image and describes the exact byte count of the decrypted payload, rather than a boundary (like min_disk). As for virtual_size, we concluded that if virtual_size eventually starts being used by some other mechanisms we might interfere with that, so we‘d like to keep it separate.

You need to explain how you see this working because one implication of this setting is that there can't be any public images in such a cloud (there are no public secrets in barbican), unless the operator has separate user-facing and admin-facing Glance nodes.  But if we're going to require separate nodes, then I think this can be handled via the container_formats config option (see below).

The unavailability of public images is a limitation of that approach in its current state. Disabling unencrypted images is a conscious decision of the cloud provider, who will limit this functionality in favor of added security. This limitation could be addressed in the future when Barbican introduces a form of secret sharing across projects, i.e. public secrets. For now, we should simply document this limitation.

We don't need a new config option for this, this can be done by simply not including 'encrypted' in the current 'container_formats' config option.  That gives you discoverability for free ('encrypted' will either appear or not appear in the response to the GET v2/schemas/image call).  The down side is that someone could still upload an encrypted image using a different container_format, but (a) such an image would be useless, and (b) you can do that now.

> simply not including 'encrypted' in the current 'container_formats'

Can you elaborate on how you suggest this to work for the creation step? From our experience, not specifying this type within 'container_formats' will lead to a

> Unable to set 'container_format' to 'encrypted'. Reason: 'encrypted' is not one of [...]"

error in the glanceclient (see [1]). The glanceclient checks '/v2/schemas/image' before making the POST request to '/v2/images' and ensures that the container_format is known to and accepted by the server (as defined in the server's config and included in the response).

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/68cb66b5d0668cf2cb06f621309b3e4e5d7fd293/glanceclient/v2/images.py#L358

Sorry, I completely misread what you're proposing here.  I thought you wanted a way to make encryption optional; you want a way to make it mandatory.  Same thing applies.  If an operator wants to allow *only* encrypted images, they could include *only* 'encrypted' in the container_formats configuration option, and then any other container_format will be rejected.  An end user will be able to discover this for themselves in the image schema.  This is consistent with Glance's behavior since schemas were introduced in v 2.0.
I see, that makes sense. I guess we can omit introducing a new configuration variable then. Thanks for the hint!
From Train onwards, Glance is not going to use OSC anymore, so you need to add this support in python-glanceclient.

ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/idlutils.py.message:
Potential dumb question from me:

Is there a reason why we can't use the built-in intersection() from python ? 

I assume it's for better memory management since yours gonna return an iterator instead of a list/set ?

Maybe we can add some comment or docstring with the reasoning behind implementing it in a different way.

e.g:

set([1,2,3]) & set([3,4,5]) & set([3,6,7]) == set([3])
set([1,2,3]) & set([4,5,6]) == set() # empty

And so on.

This is all generators/iterators. _index_lookup_internal() returns an irange() iterator, so we end up with several of those and merge_intersection() iterates over all of those exactly once, skipping any duplicates but without creating any intermediate objects and yields those values. It's the only way I could think of doing things w/o at some point storing the whole list of things in memory. If I'm missing something obvious, let me know! :D

If not, I'll add some documentation to this.

Hi,

Thanks for the explanation, it makes sense! Usually I prefer using built-in methods I agree this is a bit different cause we can avoid storing things in memory.

++ for the docstrings, as others may have the same doubts in the future when reading this code :D

container_config_scripts/manila_ffu_db_s.message:
Please check this code in these conditions:
Pre ffwd when db is queens.
In ffwd when db is stein.
Idempotency when db is train.

I worry it will fail at least in the third one.

How do you see this failing?

At any point, are we going to be executing a sync from a older version of the code to a newer version of the DB?

This script was corrected after Lukas and Jesse explained the upgrade dance that might occur during FFU, and for the need for a different kind of idempotence, one where there may indeed be a db_sync with older code, after the database has been upgraded. 

The script in the latest patch set:

a) identifies the database version, and compares it against the max version from the code
b) if the versions don't match, checks if the database version is in the versions from code, if yes - it will invoke "db sync" to catch up, since the code brings in a newer version
c) if the db version isn't in the code, it can only mean that the code is older than the database, and a sync isn't necessary.

Just to show you the idempotency, I ran these on different environments:

 stable/queens:


  ()[root@controller-1 /]# PRE_DB_SYNC_VERSION=$( sudo -u manila manila-manage db version )
  ()[root@controller-1 /]# sudo -u manila manila-manage db sync
  ()[root@controller-1 /]# POST_DB_SYNC_VERSION=$( sudo -u manila manila-manage db version )
  ()[root@controller-1 /]# echo PRE_UPGRADE_DB_VERSION: $PRE_DB_SYNC_VERSION POST_UPGRADE_DB_VERSION: $POST_DB_SYNC_VERSION
  PRE_UPGRADE_DB_VERSION: 4a482571410f POST_UPGRADE_DB_VERSION: 4a482571410f
  ()[root@controller-1 /]#  sudo -u manila manila-manage db sync
  ()[root@controller-1 /]# echo $?
  0



On stable/train:

  ()[root@controller-2 /]# PRE_DB_SYNC_VERSION=$( sudo -u manila manila-manage db version )
  ()[root@controller-2 /]# sudo -u manila manila-manage db sync
  ()[root@controller-2 /]# POST_DB_SYNC_VERSION=$( sudo -u manila manila-manage db version )
  ()[root@controller-2 /]# echo PRE_UPGRADE_DB_VERSION: $PRE_DB_SYNC_VERSION POST_UPGRADE_DB_VERSION: $POST_DB_SYNC_VERSION
  PRE_UPGRADE_DB_VERSION: 805685098bd2 POST_UPGRADE_DB_VERSION: 805685098bd2
  ()[root@controller-2 /]# sudo -u manila manila-manage db sync
  ()[root@controller-2 /]# echo $?
  0

Instance CPUs will be indexed according to the NUMA cell index and the position inside the cell. The first CPU in the first NUMA cell will be assigned with ID 0, then the first CPU of the second NUMA cell will be associated with ID 1 ... The CPUs with an ID less than value @vcpus are 'shared' CPUs, and the remaining CPUs are 'dedicated' CPUs.
I think your unittest should ensure the policy set as expected.
